div.p: iḵtu iyaṟkaip puṇarcciyiṉ piṟṟaiñāṉṟu (EV: maṟunāḷ) talaiviyiṉ (ET: talaiviyatu) vēṟupāṭu kaṇṭa tōḻi talaivi maṟaittaṟkuc colliyatu. [G1+2 note: itu talaivi vēṟupāṭu kaṇṭu ārāyun tōḻi taṉatu ārāycciyai maṟaittuk kūṟiyatu.]

This is what the confidante, who say [her] changes after the natural union, said so that SHE would keep [it] secret. (G1+2 note: This is what the confidante said, who was investigating after seeing the changes in HER, keeping her investigation secret.)

lg.l: Since you will not rise, don't cry, before strangers,notumalar talaiyē cf. KT 171.4. The point seems to be to save one's face in public (and not to give rise to gossip).
so that [you] will loose [your] graceful beauty!
[and] red-lined rain eyes like the arrows
pulled out, after the animal is thrown down, by the millet guards!
Doesn't it know of the peacock's knowing, in the nest
on the high mountain where the Vēṅkai tree sheds [its] blossoms,

burning likeThis comparison is syntactically somewhat out of the ordinary. If we assume that the -iṉ of pitiriṉ is meant as a comparison particle, it would be placed in the middle of the comparison, since kāaya "burned" is already on the metaphorical level, in other words, it would be a mix of metaphor and comparison. Or piritiṉ is simply oblique and specifies ciṟu pal, in which case it would be a real metaphor. many littleciṟu pal: here word order is strange. ciṟu need not be a second attribute, but an adverb, in this case presumably not of pal but of the subsequent kāaya: "burning a little", perhaps one way of marking the metaphor as metaphor. sparks from the iron smith-beaten

– the green-backed parakeet that seizes the dense [millet] ears?This obviously rhetorical question encapsulating the Akam message of the poem is a little complicated. My proposal is to see it as an image that mixes the emotive and the figurative level (as is typical of evocation poems). On the thematic level, the peacock represents the parents/the village who know that when the millet is being eaten by birds is time to harvest the field, and so SHE will not have the opportunity of meeting her lover there anymore, which is why she cries. The parakeet also knows of this order of things: HE will know what is going to happen and think of some other way of meeting HER, thus the consoling message of the confidante. On the symbolic level, however, the parakeet eating the millet represents secret love-making and the peacock the danger of being found out.
